text: - [Presenter] Hello, everyone.
Today, I'll be showing a new feature
for AWS Network Firewall that adds
AWS Managed Threat Signatures
with capabilities to detect threats

and block attacks against
known vulnerabilities,

so you can stay up-to-date on
the latest security threats

without writing and
maintaining your own rules.

AWS Network Firewall's
flexible rules engine
lets you define firewall rules

that give you fine-grained
control over network traffic.

This new feature allows you to
enable stateful managed rules

for intrusion detection
and prevention signatures

that protect against threats,
such as malware, botnets,
web attacks, and emerging events.
You have full visibility
into managed threat signature rule content
across 11 categories.
You can select managed rule groups to add
to your AWS Network Firewall policies,
or you can copy and modify rule groups
to meet your specific needs.

AWS Network Firewall
provides notifications
of manged rule group updates

through Amazon Simple
Notification Service, SNS.
There is no additional charge
for using AWS Managed Threat Signatures,

and you can access the
new threat signature rules

for AWS Network Firewall
using the Amazon VPC console,
or the Network Firewall API.

To start using the new AWS
Managed Threat Signatures,
go into the VPC console,

and scroll down to the
Network Firewall sub-menu.
Then select Network Firewall rule groups.

From here, we click on
AWS managed rule groups,

and then Add rule groups
to firewall policy
to add to an existing policy.
We select a policy, and then click Next.
And then we can scroll down
to Threat signature rule groups
to select the IPS rule signature rules.

In this case, we'll select
all of them, and click Next.

At the Add tags screen,
we can select Next.
And finally, we can review our selection

before clicking on the Add
rule groups to firewall policy

at the bottom of the page
to complete the process.
AWS managed rule groups can also be copied
in the case that we want to modify them.
To do this, go back to where we just were
in the Network Firewall rule groups,
and select AWS managed rule groups.

From here, select the rule
group you want to copy.

Note that there are separate
versions of rule groups,

depending on whether
you are using default,

or strict for rule
ordering in your policy.
Once inside a rule group,
I can scroll down and look at the rules,
and then select Copy rules
to copy the rules to the clipboard.
We can also use the Duplicate rule group

at the top of the menu to
create a new rule group
with the same rules.

Once we have our own custom
version of the rule group,

we have the ability to
apply modifications to it.

For more information on
AWS Network Firewall,

go to the Network Firewall
homepage listed here,

or see the AWS Network
Firewall developer guide
linked in the description below.
Hope this update has been helpful,
and thanks for watching.
